questions.text: A 3-year-old child has been brought to the paediatric emergency with the history of fever, respiratory difficulty, stridor, and drooling of saliva since yesterday. The child is in a very critical situation with a SpO2 level of 80%. What would be your immediate management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

questions.text: A 62-year-old male chronic smoker came to the ENT outpatient department with suspected glottic carcinoma referred from a PHC. He denies any pain while swallowing, weight loss, or difficulty in breathing. On indirect laryngoscopy, a lesion is noted on the true vocal cords. Which might be the initial symptom he had for glottic malignancy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The first symptom of any disorder of the glottis (=vocal cord) will be a hoarse voice.
  • Glottic cancer affects the vibratory capacity of the vocal cord, causing hoarseness. It is because of this that glottic cancer is detected early.

Clinical features of tumours of the larynx

Explanation for other options:

Odynophagia (Option A): Refers to painful swallowing, more common in supraglottic or hypopharyngeal cancers, not glottic lesions.

Dysphagia (Option B): Difficulty in swallowing usually appears later, especially when the tumour extends beyond the glottis.

Hot potato voice (Option D): Describes a muffled, thick speech typically seen in peritonsillar abscess, retropharyngeal abscess, or deep oropharyngeal infections.

questions.text: All of the following conditions affect the posterior part of the larynx except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Lupus larynx affects the anterior larynx.
  • This laryngeal involvement is a rare complication of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and can range from mild inflammation to severe airway obstruction.
  • It most commonly involves the epiglottis.
  • It is a painless condition associated with lupus of the nose and larynx.

Cricoarytenoiditis as an Initial Manifestation of Systemic Lupus Erythematosus

Explanation for other options:

Tuberculosis of the Larynx (Option A): It most commonly affects the posterior part of the larynx, particularly the interarytenoid region and the vocal processes of the arytenoid cartilages. This posterior predilection is due to the pooling of infected pulmonary secretions by gravity.

Pachydermia Laryngis (Option B): It refers to a condition characterised by thickening and heaping up of the laryngeal epithelium, predominantly in the interarytenoid region and the posterior part of the vocal cords. It is commonly associated with chronic laryngopharyngeal reflux and sometimes with smoking.

Intubation Granuloma (Option C): It is an inflammatory lesion that typically forms on the posterior third of the vocal cords, especially at the vocal process of the arytenoid cartilage. It results from mucosal trauma due to prolonged or traumatic endotracheal intubation.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male with a known history of pulmonary tuberculosis presents to the ENT outpatient clinic with progressive hoarseness. He also reports recent weight loss and low-grade fever. On suspecting TB larynx in this patient, which is not true regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • TB larynx is a painful disease associated with pulmonary TB. (Option B)
  • Laryngeal TB is usually secondary to pulmonary TB due to direct spread via infected sputum. (Option A ruled out)
  • The earliest lesions form in the posterior part of the larynx, especially the interarytenoid region. (Option D ruled out)
  • Turban epiglottitis refers to gross thickening and oedema of the epiglottis, a classic finding in TB laryngitis. (Option C ruled out)
  • Weakness of voice and painful phonation are the classical symptoms of TB larynx.

questions.text: Mouse Nibbled appearance & turban epiglottis of vocal cord is seen in:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Mouse Nibbled appearance of the vocal cord refers to the irregular, eroded appearance of the vocal cords due to tuberculous ulceration.

Turban Epiglottitis refers to a massively edematous epiglottis in tuberculous laryngitis, appearing swollen like a turban.

questions.text: Laryngopharyngeal reflux can lead to all except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Sulcus vocalis is not caused by laryngopharyngeal reflux. It is a groove or furrow along the edge of the true vocal cord, usually congenital or related to vocal abuse or scarring.

Comparison of Sulcus Vocalis and Pseudosulcus


  • A type I sulcus is a physiologic variant characterised by an intact superficial lamina propria. Patients with a type I sulcus generally have a normal voice.
  • A type II (IIa) sulcus is defined by loss of the superficial lamina propria and adherence to the vocal ligament.
  • A type III (IIb) sulcus is a medial pit-shaped sulcus with extension into the vocal ligament and potentially even into the thyroarytenoid muscle.

Explanation for other options:

Pachydermia laryngis (Option B): Thickening of the interarytenoid and posterior laryngeal mucosa caused by chronic irritation, especially due to LPR. A characteristic feature seen in patients with reflux.

Vocal nodules (Option C): Result from chronic vocal strain and inflammation. LPR may exacerbate or contribute to their formation by increasing mucosal vulnerability.

questions.text: The following statements are true about foreign bodies in the air passage in children, except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In children, vegetable foreign bodies are common, with peanuts being the most common.

  • More common in children less than 4 years of age. (Option D ruled out)

Types of foreign bodies:

  • Vegetable: Irritating, causes inflammation (e.g., peanuts).
  • Inert: Non-reactive (e.g., plastic, metal).

Levels of Obstruction

An inhaled foreign body can get stuck at three levels:

  • Laryngeal level
  • Tracheal level
  • Bronchial level

The higher the location of the foreign body, the more dangerous it is.

  • A laryngeal foreign body obstructs air entry into both lungs.
  • If the foreign body reaches one of the bronchi, at least one lung can still be ventilated, providing more time.

Tracheal Foreign Body

  • Tracheal foreign bodies are not as common.
  • A key sign of a tracheal foreign body can be an audible slap and palpatory thud (foreign body moving up and down within the tubular air column during respiration)

Bronchial Foreign Body

  • Bronchial foreign bodies are more common on the right side than the left.
  • This is because the right bronchus is more in line with the trachea and is also wider compared to the left bronchus. (Option C ruled out)
  • The triad of sudden cough, unequal air entry, and wheezing suggests a high likelihood of a bronchial foreign body.
  • In cases of suspected bronchial foreign body, the immediate recommendation is to go for a chest X-ray (PA view).

Laryngeal Foreign Body

  • The typical presentation involves choking while eating.
  • This may be accompanied by aphonia (inability to speak).
  • Laryngeal foreign body is a serious airway emergency as it blocks ventilation to both lungs.
  • First-line management for laryngeal foreign bodies is the Heimlich manoeuvre (epigastric thrusts in a backwards and upward direction). This increases thoracic pressure by pushing the diaphragm up, expelling the foreign body.

Findings on chest X-ray for bronchial foreign body include:

  • Collapse: This can be segmental or lobar, occurring because the foreign body obstructs airflow. Commonest finding.
  • Hyperinflation: This can happen if the foreign body acts like a check-valve mechanism, allowing air to enter the lung but preventing it from exiting, leading to overinflation, the second most common.
  • A normal chest X-ray is seen in early cases within 24 hours or when a foreign body causing partial obstruction with full ingress and egress of air does not produce any signs. (Option B ruled out)
  • Oesophageal coins appear in the coronal plane,
  • Tracheal coins appear in the sagittal plane because of the cartilaginous tracheal rings.

Foreign Body in Trachea

Foreign body in the Oesophagus

Airway Foreign Body

  • While flexible bronchoscopy is useful for diagnostic purposes, rigid bronchoscopy is preferred for foreign body removal because it provides a port for ventilation, ensuring the baby's safety.
  • It is crucial not to perform the Heimlich manoeuvre for bronchial foreign bodies, as this could push the foreign body upwards and obstruct the larynx, potentially leading to immediate death.

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant is brought to the emergency department with complaints of noisy breathing and mild chest retractions. On clinical evaluation, the paediatrician suspects upper airway obstruction. Which of the following is the most likely anatomical site of obstruction, considering it is the narrowest part of the infant larynx?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The infant's larynx is small and conical. The diameter of cricoid cartilage is smaller than the size of the glottis, making the subglottis the narrowest part. Paediatric endotracheal tube selection depends on this.
  • This makes it the most vulnerable area for oedema, stenosis, or obstruction (e.g., in croup, subglottic stenosis)

Explanation for other options:

Supraglottis (Option A): Includes the epiglottis, aryepiglottic folds, and false cords. It is wide and relatively collapsible, but not the narrowest segment.

Glottis (Option C): The glottis includes the vocal cords and rima glottidis, the narrowest part in adults, not infants.

Ventricle (Option D): The laryngeal ventricle is a small space between the false and true vocal cords. It does not significantly impact airflow resistance and is not the narrowest region.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with a long-standing history of hoarseness, dry throat, and frequent throat clearing. There is no history of infection or smoking. After examination diagnosis of atrophic laryngitis is made. Which of the following statements about atrophic laryngitis is not true?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Persistent cough is a common symptom of atrophic laryngitis

Atrophic Laryngitis

Atrophic laryngitis is a chronic inflammatory condition characterised by dryness, crusting, and atrophy of the laryngeal mucosa. It is often seen in patients with chronic nasal or pharyngeal dryness, and its features are similar to atrophic rhinitis.

  • More common in females
  • Especially seen in postmenopausal women (Option A ruled out)

Pathology:

  • Atrophy of the mucosa and glands of the larynx
  • Leads to crust formation that can partially obstruct the airway (Option C ruled out)

Clinical Features:

  • Hoarseness of voice, which may temporarily improve after coughing due to crust removal
  • Dry, irritating cough is common, sometimes accompanied by dyspnea if crusts are obstructive
  • Frequent throat clearing and dry throat sensation

Treatment:

  • Voice therapy
  • Steam inhalation and humidification
  • Glycerol or saline sprays to moisten the larynx (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: A 35-year-old teacher presents with complaints of hoarseness and chronic throat irritation for the past 6 months. She also reports frequent throat clearing and a sensation of something stuck in the throat, especially in the mornings. She denies smoking or recent infections. On videolaryngoscopy, the posterior part of the larynx appears erythematous, and a pseudo-sulcus is seen along the vocal cord. Which of the following conditions is most commonly associated with a laryngeal pseudo-sulcus?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Laryngeal pseudosulcus is a linear infraglottic depression seen on laryngoscopy, highly suggestive of laryngopharyngeal reflux, especially when associated with other signs like erythema, oedema of the interarytenoid region, or posterior commissure hypertrophy.
  • This sulcus is not attached to the underlying tissues, whereas a true vocal cord sulcus is adherent to the underlying tissues of the vocal cord.
  • Reflux of acid in the throat can cause
    1. Pachydermia Larynx
    2. Pseudosulcus vocalis
    3. Vocal Nodule
    4. Vocal Polyp
    5. Contact Ulcer of the Larynx
    6. Subglottic stenosis
    7. Unexplained throat pain and dry cough

Explanation for other options:

Tuberculosis (Option A): TB of the larynx causes ulcers, granulomas, or turban epiglottitis, not pseudo-sulcus.

Vocal abuse (Option B): Vocal abuse leads to vocal nodules, polyps, or phonotraumatic lesions, not pseudo-sulcus. It primarily affects the superficial lamina propria, not the subglottic region.

Overuse of steroids (Option D): Chronic steroid use may cause vocal cord atrophy or thinning, may increase the risk of fungal infections or mucosal dryness, but not pseudo-sulcus.
